_prev_prog_3.Description:
1    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



SMWE is committed to the safety of its employees and neighbors and operates the Facility as a responsible member of the community. Personnel are encouraged to continually identify methods and procedures to reduce the use of and risks associated with hazardous chemicals. This process includes protecting the community, environment, and Facility personnel by implementing technology and procedures designed to reduce the impact of any potential release of toxic chemicals. This commitment to safety is documented in the policy and compliance manuals for the Facility, which is available to all employees.



As part of SMWE?s commitment to safe and environmentally friendly operations, monthly meetings are conducted as well as other more specific operational meetings concerning safety that would include all affected employees. Input and comments from plant personnel are also key aspects of SMWE?s safety practices. By giving personnel the ability to make suggestions regarding safety and operational practices, the Facility can operate efficiently and safely. Another key element in SMWE?s safety practices consists of the regular performance of internal and third party environmental and safety audits.



2    Regulated Substance



SMWE utilizes anhydrous ammonia within the refrigeration systems at the site. The Facility uses approximately 13,200 pounds in a single closed loop.



3    Off-site Release Scenarios



SMWE has conducted an OCA based on the EPA document titled ?RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines,? and used the EPA?s RMP*Comp Version 2.01 to estimate the distance traveled to a toxic endpoint defined by the EPA regulation. This data were then used to estimate the potential impact caused by a release from each of the regulated substances.



3.1    Worst-Case Release Scenarios



As required by regulations, scenarios were considered where the entire capacity of the largest vessel for each regulated chemical at the Facility was released in 10 minutes. Although these scenarios are highly unlikely in the event of a release, it provides the local responding agencies with a maximum possible impact in the event of an accidental release. In considering these releases, the most pessimistic meteorological conditions were used. No passive or active mitigation measures were taken into account when considering these release scenarios.



3.2    Alternative Release Scenarios



Alternative scenarios were developed to assess what potential impact may occur in the event of a release that is more likely to occur than the worst-case scenarios for each of the regulated chemicals. Several possible release scenarios were considered, and the scenarios with the greatest offsite impact were chosen. In considering the alternative release scenario, the default meteorological conditions for alternative scenarios were used in RMP*Comp. These scenarios represent a more realistic release, and have a downwind distance and impact considerably smaller than the worst-case scenario. No passive or active mitigation measures were taken into account when considering these release scenarios.



4    General Accidental Release Prevention Programs and Prevention Steps



As part of the implementation of the RMP and PSM, elements of the prevention programs have been developed to manage process safety issues associated with the Facility. Each of the program elements has been developed according to OSHA and EPA regulations in order to ensure safe operating practices and conditions at the SMWE Facility.

Elements of Prevention Program 3 include the following:

?    Process Safety Information ? information regarding the hazards of anhydrous ammonia, process description, and equipment properties

?    Process Hazard Analysis ? a detailed review of the process, and recommendations to improve the safety of the systems at the Facility

?    Operating Procedures ? procedures designed to comply with regulations and provide safe practices for the systems at the Facility

?    Training ? procedures and logs for personnel training on the covered process

?    Mechanical Integrity ? manufacturer recommended maintenance procedures, schedules, and documentation

?    Management of Change ? documentation and tracking of changes that effect the process involving the regulated chemical

?    Pre-Startup Review ? prior to the startup of a new regulated process or major changes to the existing process, a review will be conducted, as required by PSM and RMP regulations

?    Compliance Audits ? documentation of tri-annual audits of the covered process

?    Incident Investigation ? documentation and investigation procedures for determining and mitigating releases

?    Employee Participation ? documentation and statement of SMWE?s commitment to providing a safe and open work place

?    Hot Work Permit ? procedures for documenting and safely performing work on or near process equipment during normal operations

?    Contractors ? policy for contractors and outside vendors that work on or near the regulated process

These elements are continually updated and reviewed through the Management System at the Facility. The Management System includes planning, organizing, implementing, and controlling different aspects of the plan. 



5    Five Year Accident History



There have been no applicable releases of anhydrous ammonia from either of the refrigeration systems at the site in the past five years.



6    Emergency Response Program



SMWE has developed an Ammonia Emergency Action Plan which includes but is not limited to the following:

?    emergency response and evacuation procedures

?    safety and health considerations

?    notification procedures

?    local emergency response agencies

?    environmental offsite consequences



7    Planned Changes



Changes determined by the PHA and considerations made during the development of this plan will be conducted in a timely manner.



8    Updates



This RMP/PSM will be updated at least every five years. The previous RMP submittal date was October 26, 2009. The RMP/PSM will also be updated within six months in the event of a change which requires a new PHA, or if the program level is altered due to a change in the process, as required by RMP/PSM regulations.
